text: :clap: <@UAVCC2X70> Code is a means to the end. We need to keep focus on the business-logic. What is it that you are building/fixing and how do we build/fix it in the fastest and most sustainable way. The future of coding is more about the people than the code. How can we get more people into this ecosystem? What tools will they need? What problems are they solving? How do they interact with computer? We already have amazing tech, it’s time to bring it to the the other 99%.

elements.text: Code is a means to the end. We need to keep focus on the business-logic. What is it that you are building/fixing and how do we build/fix it in the fastest and most sustainable way. The future of coding is more about the people than the code. How can we get more people into this ecosystem? What tools will they need? What problems are they solving? How do they interact with computer? We already have amazing tech, it’s time to bring it to the the other 99%.

text: "Where do people spend the most of their time in writing software?" In my job, seems like (1) reading code (including 3rd-party stuff with poor documentation), (2) debugging (including reading StackOverflow about error messages) (3) thinking about how to solve problems under the constraint of minimizing "risk" and changes to the zillion lines of code that are already written, (4) writing code to solve the problem, (5) refactoring code, (6) being distracted by more interesting things on the internet, (7) writing test code, (8) commit management - reviewing, writing commit messages, merging, rebasing, fiddling with task board, etc., (9) scrums/meetings, (10) searching for & reading documentation. (Disclaimer: just guessing, and reading code only comes first in low-quality codebases)
